concepts.title: Co-prime Numbers and Prime Factorisation
concepts.content: Two numbers which have only 1 as a common factor are called co-prime numbers. For example, 10 and 21 are co-primes because their only common factor is 1. Any composite number can be written as a product of prime numbers (Euclid's rule).

examples.text: Any two consecutive natural numbers are co-primes

keyPoints: Co-prime numbers have only 1 as common factor
Any composite number = product of prime numbers
Two consecutive natural numbers are always co-primes
To factorise: divide by smallest prime repeatedly
concepts.funFact: üí° The rule that every composite number can be written as a product of primes was given by the great mathematician Euclid!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 15-16: Co-prime Numbers and Prime Factorisation

concepts.title: Twin Prime Numbers
concepts.content: If the difference between two co-prime numbers is 2, the numbers are called twin prime numbers. Examples: (3,5), (5,7), (11,13), (29,31). Both numbers in the pair must be prime numbers with a difference of exactly 2.
keyPoints: Twin primes are pairs of prime numbers differing by 2
Both numbers in the pair must be prime
There are infinitely many twin primes (unproven conjecture)
Number 1 is neither prime nor composite
concepts.funFact: üåü Mathematicians still don't know if there are infinitely many twin prime pairs ‚Äî this is called the Twin Prime Conjecture!

concepts.title: HCF ‚Äî Prime Factors and Division Methods
concepts.content: The HCF (Highest Common Factor) or GCD is the greatest number that divides all given numbers. Prime factors method: factorise all numbers, find common prime factors with lowest powers. Division method: divide larger by smaller, then divide divisor by remainder ‚Äî continue until remainder = 0.
keyPoints: HCF = Greatest Common Factor of all given numbers
Prime factors method: factorise, find common factors
Division method: divide, use remainder as new divisor
If one number divides all others, it is the HCF
HCF of co-prime numbers = 1
concepts.funFact: üè™ HCF is useful in real life ‚Äî e.g., finding the largest tile size to fit a floor without cutting!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 17-19: HCF by Prime Factors and Division Method

concepts.title: LCM ‚Äî Least Common Multiple
concepts.content: The LCM is the smallest number divisible by each of the given numbers. To find LCM: factorise all numbers, take each prime factor with its highest power across all numbers. Vertical arrangement: divide by primes that divide at least two numbers.

examples.text: Runners at start: 16,24,18 min ‚Üí LCM=144 min = 2hr 24min
LCM helps add fractions: LCM(28,35)=140, easier than 28√ó35

keyPoints: LCM = smallest number divisible by all given numbers
Take each prime factor at its maximum power
LCM is useful for adding fractions with different denominators
If largest number is divisible by all others, it IS the LCM
Vertical arrangement: divide by primes step by step
concepts.funFact: üèÉ If Shreyas, Shalaka and Snehal complete laps in 16, 24 and 18 minutes, they meet again after LCM = 144 minutes!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 19-21: LCM by Prime Factors and Vertical Method

concepts.title: Relationship: HCF √ó LCM = Product of Two Numbers
concepts.content: For any two numbers, the product of their HCF and LCM equals the product of the two numbers. HCF √ó LCM = Product of the two given numbers. This relationship is used to find LCM when HCF is known, or vice versa.

examples.text: 450g jam ‚Çπ96 vs 600g jam ‚Çπ124: HCF(450,600)=150 helps compare prices
Number divided by 8,9,10,12 giving remainder 3: LCM+3=840+3=843

keyPoints: HCF √ó LCM = Product of the two given numbers
LCM = Product of numbers √∑ HCF
HCF = Product of numbers √∑ LCM
Used to find missing fourth quantity in problems
2 is HCF of any two consecutive even numbers; 1 is HCF of any two consecutive odd numbers
concepts.funFact: üõçÔ∏è HCF helps compare prices! Finding HCF of 450 and 600 makes it easy to compare cost per 150g of jam.
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 20-22: HCF √ó LCM = Product of Numbers

test.question: Which of the following is a pair of co-prime numbers?
test.explanation: 4 and 5 have only 1 as common factor, so they are co-primes.

test.question: Which of these is a twin prime pair?
test.explanation: 17 and 19 are both prime numbers with a difference of 2, making them twin primes.

test.question: The LCM and HCF of two numbers are 432 and 72. If one number is 216, what is the other?
test.explanation: HCF √ó LCM = Product of numbers. 72 √ó 432 = 216 √ó other ‚Üí other = 72√ó432√∑216 = 144.

test.question: Three bundles of string are 392m, 308m and 490m long. What is the greatest length they can be cut into without any leftover?
The smallest number divisible by 8, 9, 10, 15, 20 with remainder 5 is _____.
test.explanation: LCM(8,9,10,15,20)=360. Required number = LCM + remainder = 360 + 5 = 365... Actually LCM=360, answer is 360+5=365. Wait - the textbook problem says 8,9,10,15,20 ‚Üí LCM=360, so number = 360+5=365.

test.question: The product of two 2-digit numbers is 765 and their HCF is 3. What is their LCM?
test.explanation: HCF √ó LCM = Product of numbers. 3 √ó LCM = 765. LCM = 765/3 = 255.

keyConcepts: Co-prime numbers: two numbers with only 1 as common factor
Twin primes: prime pairs with difference of 2, e.g. (3,5), (11,13)
HCF = greatest number dividing all given numbers
LCM = smallest number divisible by all given numbers
HCF √ó LCM = Product of the two given numbers (for 2 numbers)
Prime factorisation: any composite number = product of primes (Euclid's rule)
commonMisconceptions: HCF is always a factor of LCM ‚Äî TRUE, but students often confuse HCF and LCM
LCM is always larger than both numbers ‚Äî FALSE (e.g., if one divides the other)
HCF √ó LCM = product applies to 3 numbers ‚Äî FALSE, only for 2 numbers
Co-prime numbers must both be prime ‚Äî FALSE (e.g., 4 and 9 are co-prime)
realWorldExamples: Tiling a floor: HCF gives the largest tile that fits without cutting
Adding fractions: LCM of denominators makes addition easier
Meeting point problem: runners on a circular track meet after LCM time
Cutting strings equally: HCF gives the maximum equal length pieces
Savings stall: comparing prices of jam per 150g (HCF of 450 and 600)

longAnswers.question: Explain the difference between HCF and LCM with an example of 12 and 18.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Factors of 12: 1,2,3,4,6,12. Factors of 18: 1,2,3,6,9,18. Highest common factor is 6, so HCF(12,18)=6. Multiples of 12: 12,24,36,... Multiples of 18: 18,36,54,... First common multiple is 36, so LCM(12,18)=36. HCF is greatest common factor, LCM is least common multiple.
keyPoints: HCF uses factors; LCM uses multiples.
For two numbers: number1√ónumber2 = HCF√óLCM.
Common mistake: choosing largest common multiple for LCM.

longAnswers.question: Find HCF of 84 and 126 by prime factorization.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: 84 = 2√ó2√ó3√ó7 = 2^2√ó3√ó7. 126 = 2√ó3√ó3√ó7 = 2√ó3^2√ó7. Common prime factors with smallest powers: 2^1√ó3^1√ó7^1 = 42. Therefore HCF = 42.
keyPoints: Take only common primes with minimum powers.
Prime factorization method is systematic.
Common mistake: multiplying all primes from both numbers (that gives LCM, not HCF).

longAnswers.question: Find LCM of 24, 36 and 90 using prime factors.
keyPoints: For LCM use maximum powers of each prime.
Include primes appearing in any number.
Common mistake: taking minimum powers (that gives HCF idea).

longAnswers.question: Two bells ring every 12 min and 18 min. If they ring together now, after how many minutes will they ring together again?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: They ring together again after LCM(12,18). 12=2^2√ó3, 18=2√ó3^2. LCM = 2^2√ó3^2 = 36. So they will ring together after 36 minutes.
keyPoints: Simultaneous repeating events use LCM.
Prime factors: 12=2^2√ó3, 18=2√ó3^2.
Common mistake: using HCF instead of LCM for repeating time problems.
